description: Test your knowledge of musical history, theory, and artists

questions.question: Which composer wrote 'Symphony No. 5'?
questions.funFact: He was almost completely deaf when he composed his Ninth Symphony!
questions.story: The famous opening of Beethoven's Fifth Symphony (da-da-da-dum) is often called 'fate knocking at the door'. He began working on it in 1804, during a time when he was coming to terms with his increasing deafness, making its triumphant nature even more poignant.

questions.question: What instrument is known as the 'King of Instruments'?
questions.funFact: The largest in the world has over 33,000 pipes!
questions.story: The pipe organ earned this title due to its complexity and power. Mozart called it the 'king of instruments' because it could imitate an entire orchestra. The largest one is in the Boardwalk Hall Auditorium Organ in Atlantic City, built in 1932.

questions.question: Which decade is known as the 'British Invasion' in music?
questions.funFact: The Beatles' first US TV appearance was watched by 73 million viewers!
questions.story: The British Invasion began when The Beatles appeared on The Ed Sullivan Show in February 1964. This cultural phenomenon saw British rock bands like The Beatles, The Rolling Stones, and The Who dominate American music charts, forever changing popular music.

questions.question: Who is known as the 'Queen of Soul'?
questions.funFact: She was the first woman inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame!
questions.story: Aretha Franklin's hits like 'Respect' and 'Think' became anthems for civil rights and feminism. Her powerful voice and influence earned her the title 'Queen of Soul'.

questions.question: Which famous guitarist is known for songs like 'Purple Haze' and 'Hey Joe'?
questions.funFact: He was left-handed but played a right-handed guitar flipped upside down!
questions.story: Jimi Hendrix revolutionized guitar playing with his innovative techniques and electrifying performances. His legendary set at Woodstock in 1969 included a mind-blowing rendition of 'The Star-Spangled Banner'.

questions.question: What musical term means 'to play softly'?
questions.funFact: The word comes from the Italian 'pianoforte', which means 'soft-loud'.
questions.story: The dynamic markings 'piano' (soft) and 'forte' (loud) originated in classical music. They help performers convey emotion by varying the volume of their playing.

questions.question: Which iconic album is by Pink Floyd?
options: The Dark Side of the Moon
questions.answer: The Dark Side of the Moon
questions.funFact: This album spent over 950 weeks on the Billboard charts!
questions.story: Released in 1973, 'The Dark Side of the Moon' explores themes of life, death, and mental illness. Its innovative sound and philosophical lyrics made it a cultural milestone.

questions.question: What is the highest female voice type in classical music?
questions.funFact: Famous voices include Maria Callas and Renée Fleming.
questions.story: The soprano voice is celebrated for its ability to hit the highest notes in operatic and choral music. Roles like the Queen of the Night in Mozart's 'The Magic Flute' are notoriously challenging but awe-inspiring.

questions.question: Who is often called the 'King of Pop'?
questions.funFact: 'Thriller' is the best-selling album of all time!
questions.story: Michael Jackson transformed music, dance, and music videos with hits like 'Billie Jean' and 'Beat It'. His groundbreaking 'Moonwalk' dance move debuted in 1983.

questions.question: Which classical composer started composing at the age of five?
questions.funFact: He wrote over 600 works in his short life!
questions.story: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart was a prodigy who toured Europe as a child, astounding audiences with his skill. His music remains a cornerstone of the classical repertoire.

questions.question: Which band released the album 'Rumours'?
questions.funFact: 'Rumours' has sold over 40 million copies worldwide!
questions.story: Recorded during a period of personal turmoil among band members, 'Rumours' features hits like 'Go Your Own Way' and 'Dreams'. It remains a masterpiece of rock history.

questions.question: Which jazz musician is famous for his trumpet playing and hits like 'What a Wonderful World'?
questions.funFact: His nickname was 'Satchmo', short for 'Satchel Mouth'!
questions.story: Louis Armstrong's gravelly voice and virtuosic trumpet skills brought jazz to mainstream audiences. His infectious joy in performances made him a global ambassador for the genre.

questions.question: What scale is often used in blues music?
questions.funFact: The scale has five notes and is found in many world music traditions!
questions.story: The pentatonic scale gives blues its distinctive sound, often with added 'blue notes' for expressiveness. It's also a favorite for improvisation in genres like rock and jazz.

questions.question: Which instrument was originally used to send messages?
questions.funFact: These messages could be heard from up to 7 miles away!
questions.story: Talking drums were developed in West Africa as a sophisticated communication system. The drums could mimic the tones and rhythms of spoken language, allowing messages to be relayed across vast distances. Different drum patterns represented different words and phrases.

questions.question: Which composer was also an accomplished swordsman?
questions.funFact: This musician was also a renowned astronomer and mathematician!
questions.story: Camille Saint-Saëns was not only a musical prodigy but also excelled in many other areas. He was an expert fencer, wrote scholarly articles on ancient Roman instruments, and made significant contributions to the study of acoustics. His diverse interests often influenced his musical compositions.

questions.question: Which musical note was once banned by the church?
questions.funFact: Medieval musicians called this interval 'the devil's interval'!
questions.story: During the Middle Ages, the tritone interval was considered so dissonant that it was banned from religious music. The interval spans three whole tones and was thought to evoke evil. Despite the ban, composers found creative ways to use it, and it later became an important part of blues and jazz.

questions.question: Which instrument can play notes below human hearing?
questions.funFact: The largest of these instruments has pipes longer than a football field!
questions.story: The pipe organ at the Boardwalk Hall Auditorium in Atlantic City has pipes that can produce notes at 8 Hz, well below the human hearing range of 20 Hz. These subsonic notes are felt rather than heard, creating a unique physical sensation for listeners.

questions.question: Which composer wrote music in code?
questions.funFact: This composer often hid mathematical patterns in his music!
questions.story: Johann Sebastian Bach frequently incorporated musical cryptography into his compositions. He would convert letters into musical notes using various coding systems, sometimes spelling out names or religious phrases. This practice influenced later composers and even modern musical cryptography.

questions.question: Which instrument was made from a warship?
questions.funFact: The metal from this military vessel was worth a fortune!
questions.story: The bell known as Big Ben was cast using metal from captured French warships. The process of casting such a large bell was extremely challenging, and the first attempt cracked during testing. The second and current bell has been chiming since 1859.

questions.question: Which composer never heard their most famous work?
questions.funFact: This musician continued conducting even after losing their hearing!
questions.story: By the time Beethoven composed his Ninth Symphony, he was completely deaf. At the premiere, he conducted the orchestra but had to be turned around by the soprano soloist to see the audience's standing ovation. He never heard the piece performed.

questions.question: Which instrument was originally made from armadillos?
questions.funFact: This small instrument produces surprisingly loud sounds!
questions.story: The charango, a small Andean stringed instrument, was traditionally made using the shell of an armadillo as its resonating chamber. It was developed by indigenous musicians during the colonial period in South America, possibly as a way to hide European-style instruments from Spanish authorities.

questions.question: Which song was written in complete silence?
questions.funFact: The premiere performance caused a major controversy!
questions.story: John Cage's famous composition '4'33"' consists of three movements during which no notes are played. The piece was inspired by Cage's visit to an anechoic chamber, where he discovered that absolute silence doesn't exist. The 'music' consists of ambient sounds from the performance environment.

questions.question: Which instrument requires a medical check-up?
questions.funFact: These instruments are worth millions of dollars each!
questions.story: Stradivarius violins require regular 'check-ups' by specialized violin doctors to maintain their condition. These experts use medical imaging techniques like CT scans to monitor the instruments' internal structure and prevent deterioration. Each violin has detailed medical records tracking its condition over centuries.

questions.question: Which instrument is made from ice?
questions.funFact: The instruments must be kept below freezing!
questions.story: In Sweden, musicians create horns from ice harvested from frozen rivers. Each instrument is unique and must be played in special concerts held in ice theaters to prevent melting.

questions.question: Which composer wrote upside down?
questions.funFact: He could write mirror image scores!
questions.story: Johann Sebastian Bach could compose music while reading a score upside down from across the table. This skill allowed him to write complex counterpoint pieces with multiple melodic lines.

questions.question: Which song was played in space first?
questions.funFact: The performance used a unique instrument!
questions.story: On December 16, 1965, astronauts aboard Gemini 6 performed 'Jingle Bells' using a harmonica and sleigh bells they had smuggled aboard the spacecraft.

questions.question: Which instrument uses vegetables?
questions.funFact: The instruments become soup after concerts!
questions.story: The Vienna Vegetable Orchestra creates instruments from fresh vegetables before each performance. After the concert, the instruments are used to make soup for the audience.

questions.question: Which piano has only one key?
questions.funFact: It took years to perfect the design!
questions.story: A German artist created a piano that plays only middle C. The instrument is meant to challenge the conventional understanding of what makes a musical instrument.

questions.question: Which song was banned for being too long?
questions.funFact: The song references a famous aviation event!
questions.story: Many radio stations initially refused to play 'American Pie' due to its unusual 8.5-minute length. The song's length broke conventional radio formatting rules of the time.

questions.question: Which instrument plays itself?
questions.funFact: Ancient Greeks used similar devices!
questions.story: The Aeolian harp is played by the wind passing over its strings. These instruments were popular in European gardens during the Romantic period, creating mysterious melodies without human intervention.

questions.question: Which concert lasted 639 years?
questions.funFact: The first note change took 17 months!
questions.story: John Cage's 'As Slow As Possible' began playing in 2001 in a German church and is scheduled to end in 2640. The organ was specially built for this performance.

questions.question: Which instrument requires fire?
questions.funFact: The inventor was a physicist!
questions.story: The Pyrophone, or 'fire organ,' uses controlled flames to create musical notes. Each tube contains a small flame that, when properly controlled, creates specific musical tones.

questions.question: Which composer wrote while sleepwalking?
questions.funFact: He kept composition tools by his bed!
questions.story: Tchaikovsky would sometimes compose music while sleepwalking. His brother reported finding him at his desk in the middle of the night, writing music in a trance-like state.

questions.question: Which instrument plays deepest?
questions.funFact: The size is enormous!
questions.story: The Octobass, standing 11.4 feet tall, produces notes so low that they are felt rather than heard, reaching frequencies as low as 16 Hz.

questions.question: Which concert plays longest?
questions.funFact: The composition is complex!
questions.story: Longplayer began playing in London on December 31, 1999, and will continue without repetition until 2999, using Tibetan singing bowls.

questions.question: Which organ sounds farthest?
questions.funFact: The pipes are massive!
questions.story: The Boardwalk Hall Auditorium Organ in Atlantic City is the world's largest musical instrument, with pipes that can be heard four miles away.

questions.question: Which violin costs most?
questions.funFact: The wood is unique!
questions.story: The Messiah Stradivarius, made in 1716, is the most expensive violin in the world, valued at over $20 million and never played in public.

questions.question: Which drum beats longest?
questions.funFact: The tradition continues!
questions.story: The Peace Drum Project in Whittier, Alaska has maintained a continuous drumbeat since 1971, with different drummers taking shifts around the clock.

questions.question: Which violin costs most?
questions.funFact: It's over 300 years old!
questions.story: The Lady Blunt Stradivarius violin, made in 1721, sold for $15.9 million in 2011. Named after Lady Anne Blunt, who owned it for 30 years, it's one of the best-preserved Stradivari instruments.

questions.question: Which concert was coldest?
questions.funFact: The instruments were made of ice!
questions.story: The Ice Music Festival in Norway features concerts played on instruments carved from ice in temperatures below -2°C. The instruments include ice horns, ice harps, and ice percussion, each producing unique crystalline sounds.

questions.question: Which song played longest?
questions.funFact: It will play for 1000 years!
questions.story: Longplayer, composed by Jem Finer, began playing on December 31, 1999, and will continue without repetition until 2999. It uses algorithms to generate unique combinations from a 20-minute source recording.

questions.question: Which record spins fastest?
questions.funFact: It plays from inside out!
questions.story: Jack White's 'Lazaretto' Ultra LP features a hand-etched hologram and a hidden track that plays at 78 RPM, making it the fastest-playing record commercially released.

questions.question: Which choir is largest?
questions.funFact: They filled a stadium!
questions.story: The Angel City Chorale set a world record in 2019 with 883 singers performing together at the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, California, creating an unprecedented wall of sound.

questions.question: Which concert was highest?
questions.funFact: The equipment had to be specially modified!
questions.story: In 2019, a group of musicians performed at Mount Everest Base Camp (5,364m), setting a world record for the highest altitude concert. The instruments and equipment were specially designed to work in extreme cold and low oxygen conditions.

questions.question: Which violin costs most?
questions.funFact: It's still played today!
questions.story: The Vieuxtemps Guarneri, made in 1741, sold for an estimated $16 million in 2012. Unlike many valuable violins in museums, this instrument is still used in performances, currently played by Anne Akiko Meyers on a lifetime loan.

questions.question: Which drum is largest?
questions.funFact: It requires multiple players!
questions.story: The world's largest drum, the Great Bass Drum of Glasgow, measures 5.5 meters in diameter and requires at least four people to play it. Built in 2019, it produces sounds so low they're felt more than heard.

questions.question: Which choir is biggest?
questions.funFact: They practiced for months!
questions.story: The largest choir performance was in India in 2018, featuring 121,440 participants singing in perfect harmony. The choir practiced for over six months to achieve this remarkable feat, setting a new Guinness World Record.

questions.question: Which piano floats?
questions.funFact: It's completely transparent!
questions.story: The Crystal Piano, created by Heintzman & Co., is made entirely of acrylic and appears to float on stage. It was featured in the 2008 Beijing Olympics opening ceremony, played while suspended in mid-air.
